raw_text: [Interest] is a binary version of the word sense disambiguation data from (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994)
clean_text: [Interest] is a binary version of the word sense disambiguation data from (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994).

raw_text: One set was extracted from a hand-tagged corpus (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994) and the other by our algorithm
clean_text: One set was extracted from a hand-tagged corpus (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994) and the other by our algorithm.

raw_text: There are also hybrid methods that combine several sources of knowledge such as lexicon information, heuristics, collocations and others (McRoy, 1992) (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994) (Ng and Lee, 1996) (Rigau, Asterias et al, 1997)
We also make use of these properties in formulating the empirical classifiers as described in (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994)
clean_text: We also make use of these properties in formulating the empirical classifiers as described in (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994).

raw_text: An example of the type of feature used is the part-of-speech of the word to the right; see (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994) for the other ones we use
clean_text: An example of the type of feature used is the part-of-speech of the word to the right; see (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994) for the other ones we use.

citing_paper_authors: Jingbo, Zhu | Huizhen, Wang | Eduard, Hovy
raw_text: The Interest data set developed by Bruce and Wiebe (1994) has been previously used for WSD (Ng and Lee, 1996)
clean_text: The Interest data set developed by Bruce and Wiebe (1994) has been previously used for WSD (Ng and Lee, 1996).

raw_text: There are 88,058 noun occurrences of which 70,214 are polysemous. The next significant hand tagging task was re ported in (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994), where 2,476 usages of interest were manually assigned with sense tags from the Longman Dictionary of Con temporary English (LDOCE)
clean_text: The next significant hand tagging task was reported in (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994), where 2,476 usages of interest were manually assigned with sense tags from the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English (LDOCE).

raw_text: Recent examples of this work include (Bruce and Guthrie, 1992), (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994), (McRoy, 1992)

Bigrams have been used as features for word sense disambiguation, particularly in the form of collocations where the ambiguous word is one component of the bigram (e.g., (Bruce and Wiebe, 1994), (Ng and Lee, 1996), (Yarowsky, 1995))

citing_paper_authors: Jingbo, Zhu | Huizhen, Wang | Tianshun, Yao | Benjamin K., T'sou
raw_text: The Interest data set developed by Bruce and Wiebe (1994) has been previously used for WSD (Ng and Lee, 1996)
